title.narrative: Providing Psychological Support for Refugees Residing in Sri Lanka

description.narrative: While the COVID-19 pandemic has impacted migrants worldwide and continues to pose a threat to their physical, mental, and psychosocial well-being, the most vulnerable group of migrants – refugees and asylum seekers – have been disproportionately affected and remain more vulnerable to the disease. There are approximately 1,250 refugees and asylum seekers residing in the urban settings of Sri Lanka as per the data registered under the UNHCR. This vulnerable population faces some unique challenges. Refugees can encounter challenges in accessing healthcare, receiving reliable information in their native language, and in receiving assistance from their usual support networks. The language barrier, lack of awareness on available services, non-accessibility of support networks after the COVID-19 restrictions, and the fear of discrimination can not only cause the virus to spread more rapidly in their (usually crowded) communities, but also negatively impact their mental health. A language barrier, lack of awareness on available services and the fear of discrimination prevent them from accessing government health services and have made a negative impact on this group of people’s psychological welfare. The IOM operated a 24/7 health hotline has been receiving messages from several POCs explaining their psychological distress. The proposed 10-month project aims to support this vulnerable target group with psychological consultations, referrals and follow up, in coordination with UNHCR to improve their mental health and wellbeing.
